newsitem.title: THAILAND: SE Asian Grain-Thais, Malaysia buy Argentine corn.
newsitem.headline: SE Asian Grain-Thais, Malaysia buy Argentine corn.

text.p: Thailand and Malaysia bought about 100,000 tonnes of corn from Argentina as regional business picked up after the long Christmas holiday period, traders said on Wednesday.
Charoen Pokphand, Thailand's biggest agri-business group, bought 50,000 tonnes of Argentine corn for April shipment at US$130 per tonne C&F.

Nichimen Corp of Japan said on Tuesday it sold 50,000 tonnes of corn to Malaysia, also for April shipment. Singapore-based traders said on Wednesday the price for the corn reached about $135-$136 a tonne C&f.
"The cheapest corn one can find during this time is from Argentina for that shipment period. April shipment cargoes should arrive between May-June," a Thai trader said.
"Some countries have apparently begun taking positions to cover their needs," a grains trader in Singapore said.
There have been more inquiries for a few cargoes of Argentine corn, also for April shipment, but no new buying was heard, Bangkok-based traders said.
Millers bought corn to build up stocks as imported supplies are not expected to be available until May, trade sources said.
Thai domestic corn prices edged up to 4.20-4.30 baht a kg from 4.10-4.20 baht a kg.
Industry sources forecast that Thailand will need to import about 500,000-700,000 tonnes of corn this year.
"However, it all depends on the prices of traditional substitutes of corn such as tapioca and broken rice too," said the trader.

Thai soymeal prices firmed this week on rumours that soybean shipments from the United States could be delayed, traders said. Soymeal prices rose to 9.30-9.40 baht a kg from 9.20-9.30 baht a week ago, they said.
"The rumour that U.S. soybean imported by oil crushers might be delayed by a recent accident at one of the U.S. ports triggered fears of a shortage," one trader said.
The dealer was referring to an accident last month in New Orleans when a tanker on the Mississippi river lost its steering, collided with the embankment and blocked movement of ships in the area.
But some traders said a shortage was unlikely as the expected delay of the shipment will be offset by the arrival of 34,539 tonnes of U.S. soybean due to arrive this week.

Thai buyers have also started buying soymeal, mostly of Indian-origin, to cover February and March demand. Trade sources said at least three cargoes were bought at a price ranging between $301-$304 a tonne C&F.
In Malaysia, grain traders said some shortcovering may also be seen if China exports an estimated two million tonnes of corn this year.

"We're now expecting the Chinese corn, which should come out in the next couple of weeks. But whether there'd be any buying depends seriously on the price," the purchasing manager of a flour mill in Kuala Lumpur said.
Price of bulk corn, ex-factories/godowns in Malaysia's central region, was quoted at 415 ringgit a tonne last week, compared to between 425 and 430 ringgit two weeks ago.
"A" grade wheat in bags, ex-factories/godowns in the central region, was unchanged at 800 ringgit per tonne.
The price of low-grade wheat, also central-based, was also retained at 450 ringgit a tonne.
Local soymeal was at 820 ringgit a tonne, while the imported material was at 830 ringgit, both in the central region.
Indonesian corn prices, on the other hand, were generally stable on ample stocks and rising domestic supply, traders said.
They said corn was quoted at 370-375 rupiah/kg in Jakarta, unchanged from a week ago, while soybean meal was quoted the same as last week's 795-800 rupiah/kg.

"Feed mills seem to have sufficient stocks and are sourcing from domestic sources," one trader said. "The harvest in Lampung (in South Sumatra) is proceeding well, and we expect the output to peak by mid-January."
Another trader said the corn import business seemed quiet, with feedmills having sufficient stocks and the Lampung harvest set to peak later this month.
"Imports in January are likely to be relatively low because of the harvest," he said.
Traders said players also seemed well covered on soymeal.
Data from Belawan Port showed that the MV Feng Jin arrived at the North Sumatran port on December 31 with 3,000 tonnes of soybean meal from India.
SOUTHEAST ASIAN GRAIN/MEAL PRICES: Jan 8 Dec 18
Thailand - Corn/maize (baht/kg) 4.20-4.30 4.05-4.16
Thailand - Soymeal, imported (baht/kg) 9.30-9.40 9.00
Malaysia - Corn (ringgit/tonne) 415 425-430
Malaysia - Grade A wheat (ringgit/tonne) 800 800
Malaysia - Low grade wheat (ringgit/tonne) 450 450
Malaysia - Local soymeal (ringgit/tonne) 820 820
Malaysia - Imported soymeal (ringgit/tonne) 830 810
Indonesia - Corn (rupiah/kg) 370-375 375-380
Indonesia - Soymeal (rupiah/kg) 795-800 795-800
-- Singapore Newsroom (65-8703305)
